metadata.title: Dehydrofluorination of 1, 1, 1, 3, 3-pentafluoropropane over C-AlF<ce:inf loc=post>3</ce:inf> composite catalysts: Improved catalyst stability by the presence of pre-deposited carbon

Dehydrofluorination of 1, 1, 1, 3, 3-pentafluoropropane over C-AlF3 composite catalysts: Improved catalyst stability by the presence of pre-deposited carbon Xiu-Xiu Fang a Yun Wang a Wen-Zhi Jia b Jian-Dong Song a Yue-Juan Wang a Meng-Fei Luo a ⁎ Ji-Qing Lu a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials Institute of Physical Chemistry Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hubei Polytechnic University, Huangshi, Hubei, 435003, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hubei Polytechnic University Huangshi Hubei 435003 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A series of C-AlF3 composite catalysts were prepared using a sol-gel method and different aluminum precursors (i.e. aluminum isopropoxide (Al(O i Pr)3) and aluminum diacetate hydroxide (C4H7AlO5)). These catalysts were very active in gas-phase dehydrofluorination of 1, 1, 1, 3, 3-pentafluoropane. For example, a catalyst calcined at 400 °C with aluminum isopropoxide as the precursor (denoted as C-AlF3-AIP-400) gave a reaction rate of 8.30 μmol s−1 gcat -1 and a selectivity to 1, 3, 3, 3-tetrafluoropropene (HFO-1234ze) of above 99% at 340 °C. More importantly, the C-AlF3 catalysts showed excellent stability during 100 h reaction, while the pure AlF3 catalyst suffered severe deactivation owing to the coke deposition on the surface. In contrast, pre-deposited carbonaceous species formed in the catalyst due to the incomplete decomposition of organic precursors during the preparation procedure, which blocked strong acidic sites in the AlF3 and thus maintained the catalyst stability. Therefore, these findings provide useful information on the development of efficient catalyst for this reaction, particularly on the maintainance of catalyst stability. Keywords Aluminum fluoride Dehydrofluorination Sol-gel Pre-deposited carbon 1, 1, 1, 3, 3-pentafluoropropane 1 Introduction Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) such as 1, 1, 1, 2-tetrafluoroethane (HFC-134a) have been widely used as refrigerants, but their high global warming potentials (GWP) leads to constrained reduction of their production according to the European Union’s new F-gas [1]. Therefore, it is urgent and necessary to pursue substitution of the HFCs. Hydrofluoroolefins (HFOs) with short atmospheric life time, zero ozone depletion potential (ODP) and low global warming potential (GWP) [2–4] could promisingly meet the environmentally benign requirement, and are recognized as a potential replacement of HFCs in the field of automotive refrigeration [5,6]. As a typical HFO compound, 1, 3, 3, 3-tetrafluoropropene (HFO-1234ze) is a potential new generation refrigerant and thus its synthesis attracts much attention. The main routes include F/Cl exchange reaction, fluorination of halogenated methane and halogenated ethylene [7], carbene reaction and the gas-phase dehydrofluorination of HFCs. Among these routes, gas-phase catalytic dehydrofluorination of HFC-245fa has some significant advantages, such as simple reaction process, high yield and easier continuous production, which shows an extensive prospect for the production of HFO-1234ze [8–10]. Dehydrofluorination of HFCs is an endothermic reaction, where a high temperature is necessary for considerable conversion. Generally, metal fluorides and metal oxides are the promising catalysts for gas-phase dehydrofluorination in a corrosive atmosphere (HF) and elevating temperature conditions due to their irreplaceable stability [11–14]. Among various metal fluorides, aluminum fluoride (AlF3) is a representative catalyst for this reaction due to its surface acidity which is crucial for the reaction [15,16]. However, AlF3 materials prepared via conventional route such as gas-phase fluorination and precipitation methods usually have low specific surface areas and weak acidity, and thus possess low activities in dehydrofluorination of HFCs [17,18]. The efforts to synthesize AlF3 with high surface area include hydrofluoric sol-gel method [16], plasma-etching fluorination 19], oxidation decomposition [15], carbon-template fluorination [20] and microwave hydrothermal [21]. For example, Mahmood et al. [22] reported that high-surface-area AlF3 (HS-AlF3) prepared by a sol-gel route showed high activity for the dismutation of chlorodifluoromethane due to its abundant surface Lewis acidity. Teinz et al. [23] also reported that dehydrofluorination of 3-chloro-1, 1, 1, 3-tetrafluorobutane could be selectively catalyzed on nano AlF3 catalyst synthesized via a fluorolytic sol-gel route. It is still very important but challenging for industrial applications to develop a simple synthetic method of HS-AlF3 with strong acidity and excellent stability. Unfortunately, most of the obtained high-surface-area AlF3 are amorphous [11,22], which are unstable under high reaction temperature, leading to significantly decreased surface area and collapse of porous structure. Recently, Mao et al. [24] synthesized high-surface-area α-AlF3 using a simple ethylene glycol mediated sol-gel technique which exhibited remarkably high catalytic activity for gas-phase dehydrofluorination of 1, 1, 1, 2-tetrafluoroethane. The formation of nano aluminum fluoride is due to the Al-glycolates can effectively reduce the hydrolysis of precursor and inhibit aggregation of particles, which greatly improves the stability of the prepared AlF3. Catalyst stability is vital for practical application, yet it remains challenging for the currently employed catalyst systems. Severe deactivation is commonly observed on various catalyst systems such as Cr-based catalysts [25,26], and Al-based catalysts [9] due to the coke deposition or polymerization of the product on the catalyst, which is usually related to the interaction between the reactant and the surface acid sites [9,17,27]. For example, Jia et al. [28] reported that strong Lewis acid sites resulted in rapid catalyst deactivation during dehydrofluorination of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane over a porous θ-Al2O3. Similar deactivation was also observed on Cr2O3 catalyst for the dehydrofluorination of 1,1,1,3,3-pentafluoropropane in our recent work, and the addition of NiO on Cr2O3 could alleviate such deactivation as it reduced the surface acid density [29]. Therefore, the target of this work is to develop highly active and stable catalysts for gas phase dehydrofluorination of HFC-245fa. In this work, a series of carbon-containing AlF3 catalysts were synthesized using organic aluminum precursors by a simple sol-gel method. The incomplete thermal decomposition of the precursors during the preparation procedure resulted in the formation of carbonaceous species in the catalysts. These C-AlF3 catalysts are very active and show excellent stability in the reaction. The roles of such pre-deposited carbonaceous species in the catalysts were discussed based on various characterization results. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The aluminum fluoride catalysts were prepared by a sol-gel method. The general procedure via the ethylene glycol mediated sol-gel procedure is as follows: The required amount of aluminum isopropoxide (Al(O i Pr)3) (denoted as AIP) was dissolved in ethylene glycol (50 ml) at 50 °C, and stoichiometric amount (F/Al molar ratio equal to 3) of HF solution (40 wt.%) was added to the above solution within a few minutes under rigorous stirring for 6 h until a translucent sol was obtained. The sol was aged at 90 °C for 2 days and then dried at 110 °C for 1 day to obtain the solid material. The gray gel powder was calcined at different temperatures (350, 400, 500 and 650 °C) for 4 h, with a ramp of 2 °C min−1. The obtained catalysts were designated as C-AlF3-AIP-x, where x indicated the calcination temperature. For comparison, AlF3 with aluminum diacetate hydroxide (C4H7AlO5) (denoted as ADH) and aluminum nitrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O, denoted as ANO) as the precursors were prepared using the same procedure, and the obtained catalysts were designated as C-AlF3-ADH-400 and AlF3-ANO-400, respectively. Another reference catalyst was synthesized based on the commercial AlF3·3H2O, which was calcined in air at 400 °C for 4 h with a ramp of 2 °C min−1 and denoted as AlF3-400. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The content of carbonaceous species in the catalyst can not be directly determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TG) because AlF3 could be transformed to Al2O3 at high temperature (2AlF3 + 3H2O → Al2O3 + 6 H F). Thus it was measured as follows. One gram of C-AlF3-AIP or C-AlF3-ADH catalyst was calcined at 800 °C for 4 h in static air, which was completely transformed to Al2O3 (determined by XRD). Then the content of AlF3 in the original catalyst was evaluated based on moles of Al atoms in the Al2O3, and therefore the carbonaceous content was calculated by the equation Weight of carbon = Weight of C-AlF3-AIP (or C-AlF3-ADH) - Weight of pure AlF3 in the catalyst. As the C-AlF3-AIP-650 catalyst contains a mixture of Al2O3 and AlF3, and the contents of Al2O3 and AlF3 in the original catalysts was evaluated by fitting the XRD pattern using JADE 6.5 software. Surface areas of the catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K on an NOVA 4000e apparatus. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE powder diffractometer with a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm) operated at 40 mA and 40 kV in a 2θ range from 10 to 90°. The Raman spectra of the catalysts were collected on a Renishaw Invia confocal microprobe under ambient condition (laser power = 3 mW, dwell time = 60 s, number of scans = 4, resolution = 1 cm−1). The wavelength of the excitation laser was 325 nm. Surface acidity of the catalyst was measured by ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) technique. Eighty mg of the catalyst was loaded in a home-made fixed-bed reactor (i. d. = 6 mm) and was heated in a N2 flow (30 ml min−1) from r.t. to 300 °C at a rate of 10 °C min-1. After being kept at 300 °C for 30 min, the sample was cooled down to 50 °C. Then a NH3 flow (30 ml min-1) was introduced to the reactor for 30 min, followed by purging of the sample with N2 (30 ml min-1) at 100 °C for 30 min. Then the sample was heated in the N2 flow from 50 to 800 °C at a rate of 20 °C min-1, and the profile was recorded using a mass spectrometer (Omnistar-200) monitoring m/e = 17 as well as a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Oxidation states of the surface elements in the catalysts were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) technique on an ESCALAB 250Xi instrument, with a Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV). The binding energy of F1s core level at 685.5 eV was taken as the internal standard. In situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of pyridine adsorption was performed on a Bruker TENSOR 27 FTIR spectrometer. A self-supported sample wafer was loaded in an in situ IR cell and heated from r.t. to 350 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 under vacuum. The sample was kept at 350 °C for 2 h and then cooled down to r.t., and it was exposed to pyridine vapor for 10 min at room temperature. It was then purged at 150 °C for 30 min in a He flow, followed by the spectrum recording in the range of 1200 - 1700 cm−1 with 32 scans and at a resolution of 4 cm−1. 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic dehydrofluorination of HFC-245fa was performed in a stainless steel tube reactor (i.d. = 10 mm) at atmospheric pressure. The reactor was heated by a temperature controller and mass flow controllers were used to regulate the reactant flows to the reactor. The catalyst with a weight of 0.25 g and a 40–60 mesh size was pretreated in N2 flow at 300 °C for 30 min. The reactant was a mixture of N2 and HFC-245fa with a molar ratio of n (N2) / n (HFC-245fa) = 3.4 (total flow rate = 14 ml min−1, space velocity = 1640 h–1). After reaction, the product gas was passed through a KOH solution and water to trap acid gases, then analyzed by a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a GS-GASPRO capillary column (60 m × 0.32 mm). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of the fresh catalysts Table 1 gives surface areas of the fresh catalysts. For the catalysts calcined at 400 °C, the surface area follows an order of C-AlF3-AIP-400 (97 m2 g−1) > AlF3-400 (51 m2 g−1) > C-AlF3-ADH-400 (31 m2 g−1), which might be attributed to the different natures of the Al precursors. For the C-AlF3-AIP catalysts calcined at different temperatures, the surface area gradually declines with increasing calcination temperature, which is most likely due to the sintering of AlF3 particles at high temperature. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the AlF3-400 and C-AlF3-ADH-400 catalysts, as well as the C-AlF3-AIP catalysts calcined at different temperatures. For the AlF3-400 catalyst, the diffraction peaks at 25.1, 42.3, 51.5 and 58.1° could be assigned to α-AlF3 phase (JCPDS No. 80-1007), due to the thermal decomposition of AlF3·3H2O at high temperature. The catalyst with Al(NO3)3 as the precursor also gives a structure of α-AlF3. The C-AlF3-ADH-400 catalyst shows typical diffraction of β-AlF3 phase (JCPDS No. 84-1672). These findings are in agreement with those reported by Mao et al. [24] recently, where the authors found that the high-surface-area AlF3 catalysts prepared by a sol-gel method with ADH and ANO precursors gave β-AlF3 and α-AlF3 phases, respectively. For the C-AlF3-AIP catalysts calcined at 350–500 °C, characteristic diffractions at 2 θ of 15.7, 30.4, 31.8, 45.5, 48.5, 53.1,55.7,63.2 and 68.7° could be assigned to pyrochlore-AlF3 (JCPDS No. 78-2260), and the peak intensities gradually increase with increasing calcination temperature. When the sample was calcined at 650 °C (C-AlF3-AIP-650), the crystalline structure changes to a mixture of α-Al2O3 phase and pyrochlore-AlF3. The formation of α-Al2O3 was due to the reaction 2AlF3 + 3H2O → Al2O3 + 6 H F at high temperature (i.e. 650 °C), which has been reported in literature [30,31]. These findings suggest that both the Al precursors and thermal treatment exert great influence on the resulting crystalline structures, which is probably due to different hydrolysis rates of the Al precursors when HF is used in the procedure [16]. Although the XRD results (Fig. 1) do not detect the presence of carbon in the catalysts, the colors of the catalysts differ much, as shown in Fig. 2 . The AlF3-400 catalyst derived from the commercial AlF3·3H2O is plain white, which is a typical color of AlF3. However, the C-AlF3-ADH-400 has a color of light brown while the C-AlF3-AIP-400 has a color of black, which implies that these sample may contain carbonaceous species due to the incomplete decomposition of organic precursors during the calcination process. When the C-AlF3-AIP catalyst was calcined at higher temperature (i.e. 650 °C, C-AlF3-AIP-650), the color turns to light gray, indicating that the content of carbonaceous species declines due to higher extent of decomposition of organic compounds. UV Raman spectroscopies were conducted to further verify the presence of carbonaceous species in the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3 , the AlF3-400 and AlF3-ANO-400 catalysts show no distinct Raman bands at 800 - 1800 cm−1, suggesting the absence of carbonaceous species in this catalyst. In contrast, the C-AlF3-ADH-400 and C-AlF3-AIP catalysts calcined at different temperatures show a weak band at 1360 cm−1 and a distinct band at 1620 cm−1, which could be assigned to the A1g vibration mode of the disordered amorphous carbon (D-band) and the E2g vibration mode of the ordered graphitic carbon (G-band) [32,33]. Also, the very low peak intensity ratios (ID/IG) suggest that the main carbonaceous species in the catalysts are in form of graphite. Therefore, the Raman spectroscopic results verify the presence of carbonaceous species in the catalysts with organic precursors, which may affect the catalytic performance of the catalysts [34]. The analysis of the C contents in the catalysts reveals that the C-AlF3-AIP-350 has the highest C content (30.1 wt.%) while the C-AlF3-AIP-650 has the lowest value (15.7 wt.%) because higher temperature calcination in air may thermally decompose more organic ligands. Also, different contents of carbonaceous species in the catalysts explains well the changes in the catalyst colors (Fig. 2). Surface acidic properties of the fresh AlF3-400, AlF3-ANO-400, C-AlF3-ADH-400 and C-AlF3-AIP-400 catalysts were characterized by NH3-TPD, as well as FTIR spectroscopy of pyridine adsorption (Fig. 4 ). The fresh AlF3-400 catalyst gives a broad NH3 desorption peak in temperature range of 100–550 °C, suggesting it has weak, medium and strong surface acidic sites. And the surface acidic sites is quantified as 90.0 umol g−1. The fresh C-AlF3-ADH-400 and C-AlF3-AIP-400 catalysts show similar profiles, and the surface acidic sites are 18.2 and 50.6 umol g-1, respectively. The lowered surface acidity on the C-AlF3-ADH-400 catalyst compared to that on the C-AlF3-AIP-400 is owing to their crystalline structures (β-AlF3 for the C-AlF3-ADH-400 and pyrochlore-AlF3 for the C-AlF3-AIP-400, Fig. 1). It is also found that the surface acidity of the C-AlF3-AIP catalysts gradually decreases with increasing calcination temperature. The surface acidity of the C-AlF3-AIP-350, C-AlF3-AIP-400, C-AlF3-AIP-500 and C-AlF3-AIP-650 catalysts are 48.9, 50.6, 39.7 and 12.7 umol g-1, respectively. The lowest surface acidity of the C-AlF3-AIP-650 catalyst could be related to its lowest surface area (23 m2 g-1, Table 1) and its crystalline nature (a mixture of α-Al2O3 and pyrochlore-AlF3, Fig. 1). The AlF3-ANO-400 catalyst with Al(NO3)3 as the precursor has the largest surface acidity (94.5 umol g-1). Moreover, the broad NH3-TPD profiles were deconvoluted to different acid strength, namely, weak acid sites between 100–200 °C, medium acid sites between 200–400 °C and strong acid sites between 400–550 °C. It is clear that the concentrations of strong acid sites in the C-AlF3-AIP-400 and C-AlF3-ADH-400 (7.3–7.4 %, 3.7 and 1.4 umol g-1, respectively) is much lower than that in the AlF3-400 (14.5%, 13.1 umol g-1). It implies that the carbonaceous species in the former catalysts may block some strong acid sites in the catalysts. This speculation is further verified by the comparison of the C-AlF3-AIP-400 and C-AlF3-AIP-500 catalysts, as the C-AlF3-AIP-400 has a lower concentration of strong acid sites (7.3%, 3.7 umol g-1) than the C-AlF3-AIP-500 (9.1%, 3.5 umol g-1) because of its higher carbon content (29.2% versus 25.5%). The AlF3-ANO-400 catalyst has the highest concentration of strong acid (18.4%, 17.4 umol g-1). Fig. 4b demonstrates the FTIR spectra of pyridine adsorption on the catalysts. The bands at 1455,1498, 1600 and 1623 cm-1 can be observed in all the measured catalysts, which are commonly assigned to pyridine coordinated to Lewis acid sites [35,36]. The absorption band at 1545 cm−1 is not observed, indicating that the prepared catalysts possess no Brønsted acidity [37]. Also, the band intensities of the fresh AlF3-400 are higher than those of the C-AlF3-AIP-400 and C-AlF3-ADH-400, implying its higher quantity of surface acidic sites which is consistent with the NH3-TPD results (Fig. 4a). 3.2 Dehydrofluorination of HFC-245fa over various catalysts Fig. 5 illustrates the catalytic behaviors of the catalysts at different reaction temperatures. Since all the catalysts shows very high selectivities to HFO-1234ze (almost 100%, Table 1), only the conversions of HFC-245fa are presented. All the catalysts give rising HFC-245fa conversions at elevated reaction temperatures, and the conversions are closed to 100% when the reaction temperature is up to 400 °C. For the catalysts calcined at 400 °C, the activity follows an order of C-AlF3-AIP-400 > AlF3-ANO-400 > AlF3-400 > C-AlF3-ADH-400. The C-AlF3-AIP-400 catalyst has the highest activity, with the conversion of 76.3% at 340 °C, while the C-AlF3-ADH-400 catalyst gives the lowest conversion (23.5%). For the C-AlF3-AIP catalysts calcined at different temperatures, it is found that the conversion follows an order of C-AlF3-AIP-350 ≈ C-AlF3-AIP-400 > C-AlF3-AIP-500 > C-AlF3-AIP-650. Table 1 summarizes the catalytic results of various catalysts. At the reaction temperature of 340 °C, the highest reaction rate is obtained on the C-AlF3-AIP-400 catalyst (8.30 μmol s−1 gcat -1), which is higher than those reported on fluoride-based catalysts (i.e. 2.11 μmol s-1gcat −1 over the AlF3-AOH catalyst [38]; 2.68 μmol s-1gcat -1 over the V2O5/MgF2 catalyst [39]) and is comparable to those reported on Cr-based catalyst (i.e. 11.6 μmol s-1gcat -1 over the Cr2O3 catalyst and 16.8 μmol s-1gcat -1 over the NiO/Cr2O3 catalyst [29]). Fig. 5b shows stability of the C-AlF3-AIP-400, C-AlF3-ADH-400 and AlF3-400 catalysts at reaction temperature of 300 °C. The HFC-245fa conversions on the C-AlF3-AIP-400, AlF3-ANO-400 and AlF3-400 catalysts are both high in the first 0.5 h (80–85%). However, the AlF3-400 gradually deactivates during the reaction, with the conversion declined to 47.8% after 100 h reaction. The AlF3-ANO-400 exhibits a even more rapid deactivation rate than the AlF3-400, with the drop of conversion by about 20% in 30 h reaction. However, it is interesting to find that the conversion of the AlF3-AIP-400 catalyst slightly increases from 80.2% at 1 h to 90.3% at 100 h. Meanwhile, the conversion of the C-AlF3-ADH-400 catalyst is stable (34.3%) during 30 h reaction. It is worthwhile to discuss different behaviors of these catalysts. First of all, the activities of the catalysts are closely related to their surface acidity (i.e. acid strength and the quantity of surface acid sites), which is considered as a crucial parameter [24,28] although their roles depend on the nature of the reactants. For example, Li et al. [40] reported that weak acid sites in the Mg2P2O7 catalyst are the active sites for the dehydrofluorination of 1,1,1-trifluoroethane to 1,1-difluoroethylene; Jia et al. [28] concluded that the weak Lewis acid sites in a porous θ-Al2O3 are responsible for the formation of 1,1, 1-trifluoroethylene by dehydrofluorination of 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane; Teinz et al. [23] concluded that the strong Lewis acid sites in the AlF3 catalyst are responsible for the dehydrofluorination of 3-chloro-1,1,1,3-tetrafluorobutane. In the current work, the correlation between surface acidity and reaction rate shown in Fig. 6 clearly indicates that the rates of the catalysts at 300 °C generally follow the order of their surface acidity, that is, the catalyst with higher surface acidity is more active than that with lower surface acidity. For example, the C-AlF3-AIP-350 and C-AlF3-AIP-400 with similar surface acidity (48.9–50.6 μmol g−1, Fig. 4) have similar rates (8.14–8.30 μmol s−1gcat −1, Table 1), which are higher than that on the C-AlF3-AIP-500 (6.31 μmol s−1gcat −1, Table 1) as the latter has low surface acidity (39.7 μmol g−1, Fig. 4a). It should be noted that the surface acidity is related to the crystalline structures of the catalysts, as clearly evidenced by the XRD results (Fig. 1). However, the exception that the AlF3-400 and AlF3-ANO-400 with the highest surface acidity (90.0 and 94.5 μmol g-1 respectively, Fig. 4) do not have the highest best performance indicates that not all the surface acid sites participate in the reaction or the strong acid sites in the catalysts have very limited contribution in the reaction. To verify this point, turnover frequencies (TOFs) based on surface acidity of the catalysts were calculated, as shown in Fig. 6. All the catalysts show similar TOFs values (0.145 - 0.180 s-1, Table 1) except for the AlF3-400 (0.085 s-1) and the AlF3-ANO-400 (0.083 s-1). The similar TOFs on the catalysts suggest that only the weak and medium acid sites on the catalyst surface are responsible for the activity since the catalysts (except for the AlF3-400 and AlF3-ANO-400) possess minimal quantities of strong acid sites (NH3-TPD results, Fig. 4a). On the contrary, the AlF3-400 and AlF3-ANO-400 catalysts with high contents of strong acid sites have the lowest TOF, implying that the strong acid sites on the AlF3 may not be involved in the reaction. To further quantify the contributions of different acid sites in the reaction, a rough analysis is conducted based on the following equation : TOFtotal = C1 * TOF1 + C2 * TOF2 + C3 * TOF3, where C1, C2 and C3 are the relative concentrations of the weak, medium and strong acid sites in the catalyst (calculated based on the results in Fig. 4a), respectively ; TOF1, TOF2 and TOF3 are the turnover frequencies of the weak, medium and strong acid sites in the catalyst, respectively; TOFtotal is the obtained overall turnover frequency on the catalyst (as shown in Table 1 and Fig. 6). Assuming that the same kind of acid site (weak, medium or strong) is different catalysts has the same TOF (regardless of the crystalline structure), the TOFs of different acid sites could be calculated using multi-linear regression of the results on the catalysts. The calculated values are TOF1 = 0.202 s-1, TOF2 = 0.232 s-1, TOF3 = -0.619 s-1. The positive values of TOF1 and TOF2 suggest that the weak and medium acid sites in the catalysts have similar intrinsic activities, while the negative value of TOF3 implies that the strong acid sites play inhibiting role in the reaction. These findings in the current work therefore suggest that the weak and medium acid sites in the catalysts are the active sites for the reaction. The roles of pre-deposited carbonaceous species in the catalytic activity could be further illustrated by comparing the behaviors of the C-AlF3-AIP-350, C-AlF3-AIP-400 and C-AlF3-AIP-500 catalysts as they have the same crystalline structure (pyrochlore-AlF3, Fig. 1). In spite of their different C contents (25.5–30.1 wt. %), these catalysts show similar TOFs (0.160 - 0.164 s-1 at 300 °C, Table 1), indicating that the pre-deposited carbonaceous species do not affect the activity because they selectively block the strong acid sites in the catalysts which are not active in the reaction (as confirmed by its negative TOF value). Catalyst stability is another crucial parameter in chemical reaction, particularly in practical applications. The most interesting observation in the current work is that the C-containing catalysts (C-AlF3-AIP and C-AlF3-ADH) are very stable during long-term reaction while the bare AlF3 and AlF3-ANO-400 catalysts suffer severe deactivation (Fig. 5b). Since the bare AlF3-400 and AlF3-ANO-400 catalysts have abundant strong acid sites (Fig. 4a), it is reasonable to assign the catalyst deactivation to the presence of such strong acid sites, which is also justified by its negative TOF value. In contrast, when the organic Al precursors are used in the preparation process, the formed carbonaceous species somehow diminish the strong acid sites of the AlF3, which avoids the coke deposition during the reaction and thus maintain the catalyst stability. 3.3 Characterizations of the spent catalysts To further investigate the possible surface species of the catalysts after reaction, various characterizations were conducted. Fig. 7 compares the UV-Raman spectra of the fresh and spent AlF3-400, AlF3-ANO-400, C-AlF3-AIP-400 and C-AlF3-ADH-400 catalysts. The fresh and spent C-AlF3-AIP-400 and C-AlF3-ADH-400 catalysts show very similar spectra, indicating that there is no additional surface species after reaction. However, the spent AlF3-400 and AlF3-ANO-400 catalysts show a relatively weak band at 1360 and a strong band at 1620 cm−1 assigned to deposited carbon in amorphous and mainly graphitic forms, respectively [32,33]. This comparison vindicates that the deactivation of the AlF3-400 and AlF3-ANO-400 catalysts is due to the deposited carbon on the catalyst surface. The C1s XPS spectra of the fresh and spent catalysts were measured to give detail analyses of the surface carbon species, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . The fresh AlF3-400 catalyst (Fig. 8a) contains a broad band due to the adventitious carbon, which could be further deconvoluted to three component at binding energies (BEs) of 285.1, 286.1 and 287.5 eV due to CH, COH, CO, respectively [41]. These three components are observed in all the fresh and spent catalysts. For the spent AlF3-400, two additional components at BEs of 284.5 and 289.3 eV are observed, which are assigned to CC of carbon in graphitic form and carboxyl groups, respectively [42]. This suggests the formation of carbonaceous species on the AlF3-400 during the reaction, which is well consistent with the UV-Raman results (Fig. 7). For the fresh C-AlF3-AIP-400 and C-AlF3-ADH-400 catalysts, the components at BEs of 284.5 and 289.3 eV are observed in addition to those at 285.1, 286.1 and 287.5 eV, suggesting the presence of graphitic carbon and carboxyl groups in the fresh catalysts due to the incomplete decomposition of the organic Al precursors. Also, an additional component at BE of 292.4 eV is observed on the spent C-AlF3-AIP-400 due to the carbon in CF bond [43]. Also, the analyses of the relative concentrations of different carbonaceous species in the fresh and spent catalysts (Table 2 ) reveal that the spent AlF3-400 catalysts contains a significantly high concentration of graphitic carbon species (peak at BEs of 284.5 eV, 47.5%), which accounts for its rapid deactivation. On the contrary, such concentrations in the spent C-AlF3-AIP-400 and C-AlF3-ADH-400 catalysts only increase by 7.9 and 7.0%, respectively, which explains well the good stability of these two catalysts. 4 Conclusions This work demonstrated an simple but effective strategy for the synthesis of high performance AlF3 catalysts for the dehydrofluorination of HFC-245fa. The pre-deposited carbonaceous species in the catalyst due to the incomplete thermal decomposition of organic ligands during the preparation procedure results an unexcepted excellent catalyst stability, without losing its activity. Various characterizations reveal the catalytic performance is closely related to the surface acidity of the catalyst, and the roles of different acid sites in the reaction are verified. It is believed that the weak and medium acid sites are the active sites for the reaction, while the strong acid sites are responsible for the coke deposition during the reaction and thus the catalyst deactivation. With the blockage of strong acid by inert carbonaceous species, the catalyst could be stabilized. This strategy might be also applied to other systems such as Cr-based catalysts, which also suffer deactivation during dehydrofluorination reaction because of the deposition of coke species on the strong acid sites. coredata.dc:description: A series of C-AlF3 composite catalysts were prepared using a sol-gel method and different aluminum precursors (i.e. aluminum isopropoxide (Al(O i Pr)3) and aluminum diacetate hydroxide (C4H7AlO5)). These catalysts were very active in gas-phase dehydrofluorination of 1, 1, 1, 3, 3-pentafluoropane. For example, a catalyst calcined at 400 °C with aluminum isopropoxide as the precursor (denoted as C-AlF3-AIP-400) gave a reaction rate of 8.30 μmol s−1 gcat -1 and a selectivity to 1, 3, 3, 3-tetrafluoropropene (HFO-1234ze) of above 99% at 340 °C. More importantly, the C-AlF3 catalysts showed excellent stability during 100 h reaction, while the pure AlF3 catalyst suffered severe deactivation owing to the coke deposition on the surface. In contrast, pre-deposited carbonaceous species formed in the catalyst due to the incomplete decomposition of organic precursors during the preparation procedure, which blocked strong acidic sites in the AlF3 and thus maintained the catalyst stability. Therefore, these findings provide useful information on the development of efficient catalyst for this reaction, particularly on the maintainance of catalyst stability.
coredata.dc:title: Dehydrofluorination of 1, 1, 1, 3, 3-pentafluoropropane over C-AlF3 composite catalysts: Improved catalyst stability by the presence of pre-deposited carbon
